Help 6th-12th graders learn to program by joining ICSpark, an organization created by ICS students to provide free introductions to coding on Saturdays.  

All of our programs are free, geared towards 6th - 12th grade students and lead by undergraduate mentors. No prior coding knowledge is required. Parents and students will attend a mandatory orientation at the beginning of the program semester prior to the beginning of classes. Classes will be held at the computer labs in the Pacific Ocean Science and Technology (POST) building on the University of Hawaii at Manoa campus. 

They are looking for passionate, kind and patient undergraduate computer science mentors who are willing to be role models for the our next generation of coders. Mandatory training is provided prior to exposure to the classroom. Email us with your current resume, availability, and reasons for applying to become a mentor.

For more information, see [https://icspark.github.io/website/](https://icspark.github.io/website/).

contents.name: ITMA
contents.description:
Join the Information Technology Management Association to network with students from the Information Technology Management (ITM) program in the Shidler College of Business.

The ITMA is motivated and dedicated to provide its members social and professional relationships, provide access to technical resources, and be an example of a growing technical environment to foster career development.

Learn more at [http://itmahawaii.com/](http://itmahawaii.com/).

contents.name: JSConf Hawaii
contents.description:
Participate in JSConf Hawaiʻi, an annual three day conference on Javascript, to learn about innovations in the JS ecosystem and meet leaders in the field. 

For our second year, we're planning to bring about 400 people together for a three-day single track conference at the Alohilani Resort in Waikiki from February 5-7. 

Our goal is that by the time you leave, you'll have seen some new ideas, learned some more JavaScript, and made new friends to keep in touch with.

The small, single-track nature of the conference means that it's easy to figure out what to do! We'll have lots of time to meet your fellow attendees and share ideas outside of the sessions.

For more information, see [https://www.jsconfhi.com/](https://www.jsconfhi.com/).

Note that you can [apply for a scholarship](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfifk0on5yj014741vEP2lDWX6DF9ADc6PFZ8nPftfhwba9IQ/viewform) until October 15.

contents.name: Jupyter Education Widgets
contents.description:
If you're interested in data science, Python, and/or educational technology, then this research project on adding educational widgets to Jupyter Notebooks will be of interest to you!

This project will develop new widgets that integrate with Jupyter Notebook to instrument student learning and to provide instructors with valuable insight on students’ progress, and on the clarity of their training material and its effectiveness in conveying the desired course objectives. 

Students will have the responsibility to maintain the set of existing JavaScript components and work on new widgets and functionality. 

In data science, Jupyter notebooks are the platform-of-choice for tutorials, workshops, online lessons, and increasingly for publishing online data science books. As such, the widgets we propose stand to benefit a large audience.

The selected intern will gain valuable experience in software engineering and data science, as well as exposure to the Jupyter Notebook API.

Minimum qualifications:
* Python (intermediate or advanced), 
* JavaScript (Intermediate or advanced), 
* Front-end development in HTML and CSS (Intermediate or advanced), 
* GitHub or other Git-based repository hosting services, 
* Familiarity with software development best practices

Desired qualifications. 
* Google Firebase, 
* Flask Framework 

For details and to apply, please contact Mahdi Belcaid (mahdi@hawaii.edu).

contents.name: Kaggle
contents.description:
Improve your skills in data science and sharpen your interview preparation by participating in a Kaggle online competition.

[Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/) is an online service that hosts data science and machine learning competitions, as well as a job board with listings for analysts, programmers, and more.  If you are interested in a career in data science, you should definitely get involved with Kaggle!

Kaggle has been used by over 800,000 data scientists to explore, understand, and contribute to machine learning and data analytics.

The Kaggle community has worked together to utilize machine learning for everything from essay marking to diagnosing heart failure. Last August, Kaggle launched an open data platform in which scientists have contributed a range of datasets relating to everything from credit card fraud to H-1B Visa petitions and tsunami wave rates.

To gain ICE points for this opportunity, join Kaggle, and then work through the [Titanic](https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic) competition. 

Learn more at [https://www.kaggle.com/](https://www.kaggle.com/)

contents.name: Lava Lab
contents.description:
Working in the Laboratory for Advanced Visualization & Applications (LAVA) Research Lab will give you skills and experiences at the cutting edge of hardware and software for data visualization and virtual/augmented reality. 

The mission of LAVA is to conduct research and development in big data visualization techniques, and to apply these techniques in cutting edge domain science, engineering, and training applications. 

Learn more at [http://lava.manoa.hawaii.edu](http://lava.manoa.hawaii.edu).

contents.name: National Cyber League
contents.description:
If you want to sharpen your practical skills in cybersecurity, then you'll accomplish that and have fun as well in this puzzle-based, capture-the-flag style cybersecurity competition. 

Its virtual training ground helps high school and college students prepare and test themselves against cybersecurity challenges that they will likely face in the workforce. All participants play the games simultaneously during Preseason, Individual Game and Team Game.

NCL allows players of all levels to enter. Between easy, medium and hard challenges, students have multiple opportunities to really shine in areas as they excel.

The NCL challenges are based on the CompTIA Security+™ and EC-Council Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH)™ performance-based exam objectives and include the following content: Open Source Intelligence, Scanning, Enumeration and Exploitation, Password Cracking, Traffic Analysis, Log Analysis, Wireless Security, Cryptography, and Web Application Security.

Collegiate students benefit because the NCL competition is closer to workplace experience over that of formal education by stressing application over theory.  The NCL also helps students train for other collegiate level competitions such as the Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition and prepares them for the workplace. 

For more details, see [https://www.nationalcyberleague.org/](https://www.nationalcyberleague.org/)

contents.name: Parallel Data Structures
contents.description:
This research project led by Professor Nodari Sitchinava will expose you to techniques to design data structures which can be built efficiently in parallel and/or queried efficiently in parallel.

The resulting data structures are used in multicore, GPU and MapReduce algorithms and implementations.

Relevant courses: ICS 311, ICS 443, ICS 621, ICS 643, ICS 691C.

This project is sponsored by the [AlgoPARC](http://algoparc.ics.hawaii.edu/) research group.

contents.name: Purple Mai'a
contents.description:
Volunteer with the Purple Maiʻa Foundation if you would like to help create access to empowering technology education for underserved youth in Hawaii.

Purple Maiʻa’s mission is to build channels of technological knowledge together with the Hawaiʻi’s youth in order to help communities thrive.

We teach coding and computer science through after school and elective classes to Native Hawaiian students, low-income youth, and others who are underrepresented in tech. As we increase access to tech education we also ground students in the knowledge that their ancestors were indigenous innovators who used their skills and perspective to serve their communities and lands.

Since 2016, the Purple Prize has empowered the people of Hawaiʻi to create impactful technology startups that are truly rooted in Hawaiian values. To date, we have worked with over 40 teams and have awarded those with the highest potential to create real impact in Hawaiʻi nei.

Learn more at [http://www.purplemaia.org/](http://www.purplemaia.org/).

contents.name: PyHawaii
contents.description:
Join the PyHawaii Meetup Group if you want to connect with other local Python enthusiasts for tutorials, projects, mentoring, sprints and other activities.

All skill levels are welcome! 

At PyHawaii, like PyCon, we are all about community, inclusivity and ohana - so come join our meetup, where you will find friends, family and fantastic opportunities to learn, grow, contribute and advance your skills. 

Learn more at [https://www.meetup.com/PyHawaii-Python-Users-Group/](https://www.meetup.com/PyHawaii-Python-Users-Group/)

contents.name: Python and Django web dev course
contents.description:
Take this Udemy course if you want to learn to build websites using HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, Javascript, jQuery, Python 3, and Django.

According to the course home page, "This course is designed so that anyone can learn how to become a web developer. We teach you how to program by using HD Video Lectures, Walkthrough Code Projects, Exercises, Concept Presentation Slides, Downloadable Code Notes, Reading Assignments, and much more!"

There are 32 hours of videos.

For more information, see [Python and Django Full Stack Web Developer Udemy Course Home Page](https://www.udemy.com/course/python-and-django-full-stack-web-developer-bootcamp/).

contents.name: RadGrad
contents.description:
If you've got problems with this system, don't just complain, join the RadGrad Project and fix it! 

See an interface that you could make better? Don’t get mad, get RadGrad! Join the RadGrad team and contribute to a real world system that students just like you will use. RadGrad started from the idea that students should have the chance to find what they are passionate about in the vast world of computer science, which is surprisingly not just about video games. 

Developers on the RadGrad team use Javascript, Meteor, git, Github, Semantic UI, chai, mocha, and Galaxy. So, ICS 314 is a big plus! 

If you are interested, check out the project at [http://radgrad.org](http://radgrad.org). Then come to one of our weekly meetings (contact Philip Johnson for details).

contents.name: SACNAS: The National Diversity in STEM Conference
contents.description:
If you're interested in diversity and inclusion in STEM, please consider attending SACNAS: the national diversity in STEM conference.

The largest multidisciplinary and multicultural STEM diversity event in the country, 2019 SACNAS is a 3-day conference which serves to equip, empower, and energize participants for their academic and professional paths in STEM. Over the course of the three days, college-level through professional attendees are immersed in cutting-edge scientific research and professional development sessions, motivational keynote speakers, a Graduate School & Career Expo Hall, multicultural celebrations, and an inclusive and welcoming community of peers, mentors, and role models. At 2019 SACNAS, you can shape your own STEM story inspired by your ancestors, mentors, and peers –nourished by diversity and fueled by passion for discovery.

SACNAS 2019 will be held in Honolulu, HI, from October 31 - Nov 2.  Scholarships may be available to support registration fees through UH.

For more information, see [https://www.2019sacnas.org/](https://www.2019sacnas.org/).

contents.name: Sadowski Lab
contents.description:
If you're interested in machine learning and/or data science, consider joining Professor Peter Sadowski's research group to work on interdisciplinary projects including astronomy, high-energy physics, oceanography, climate science, and cancer screening through medical imaging. 

Undergraduates who are interested in machine learning and data science are encouraged to ask Dr. Sadowski about opportunities, which could include summer research (UROP), suggestions for class projects, or guidance on a Kaggle competition. Our group values skills in Python programming, data analysis in Jupyter, math/statistics coursework, Linux systems, and High-Performance Computing. 

For more information, see [https://www2.hawaii.edu/~psadow/](https://www2.hawaii.edu/~psadow/).

contents.name: Business Plan Competition
contents.description:
Connect with undergraduates from the business school and develop your entrepreneurial chops by participating in the annual Shidler Business Plan competition, an intense and unique semester-long learning opportunity for UH students who aspire to pursue a business venture. 

The competition provides mentorship, training and resources. Winners walk away with a wealth of business savvy and substantial cash prizes. 

Learn more at: [http://pace.shidler.hawaii.edu/bpc](http://pace.shidler.hawaii.edu/bpc).

contents.name: Society of Women Engineers at UH Manoa
contents.description:
People of all genders are invited to join the UHM Society of Women Engineers to promote women in engineering. 

Through SWE events, SWE members build community, network with local professional female engineers, demonstrate the value of diversity and expand the image of the engineering profession as a positive force in the quality of life.

For more information, see [http://uhm.swe.org/](http://uhm.swe.org/)

contents.name: SWITCH-UHM
contents.description:
Join SWITCH-UHM (Supporting Women in Information, Technology and Computing in Hawaii at the University of Hawaii at Manoa) to help support women and minorities in computer science.

SWITCH-UHM is a student-run club whose purpose to support women and minorities, promote gender and racial equality, create an environment and atmosphere where women can feel safe, prevent violence against women by raising awareness of campus resources, facilitate professional events such as interview prep and seminars, and provide an overall sense of community. 

While this group was created by students in the ICS Department, membership is open to students of all genders and majors. However, the only requirement to join is that you must share the vision of promoting gender equality in the fields of Information, Technology and Computing. Members can benefit from the Girls Who Code College Loops education materials, professional talks and educational outreach events organized by SWITCH-UHM and funding opportunities to attend various professional conferences hosted in Oahu. Students can also benefit from SWITCH-UHM’s community focused atmosphere and other personal development events such as mixers and socials.

People of all genders can be members of SWITCH!

For more information, please see [https://switch-uhm.github.io/](https://switch-uhm.github.io/) or email switch@hawaii.edu.

contents.name: Teaching or Tutoring
contents.description:
If you want to get teaching experience while you are an undergraduate, this opportunity involves being a lab assistant in the ICS Department (through ICS 390) or serving as a tutor in the Nat Sci Learning Emporium.

For more details,  see [http://courses.ics.hawaii.edu/syllabuses/ICS390.html](http://courses.ics.hawaii.edu/syllabuses/ICS390.html), or  [http://natsci.manoa.hawaii.edu/learningemporium.php](http://natsci.manoa.hawaii.edu/learningemporium.php).  

Learn more about the benefits of teaching as an undergraduate at [http://cacm.acm.org/blogs/blog-cacm/189498-top-10-myths-about-teaching-computer-science/fulltext](http://cacm.acm.org/blogs/blog-cacm/189498-top-10-myths-about-teaching-computer-science/fulltext).

contents.name: Technology Outreach Hawaii
contents.description:
Join Technology Outreach Hawaii (TORCH) if you want to work with other Hawaii students and partner with libraries and community organizations across the state to offer student-driven digital literacy initiatives.

Technology Outreach Hawaii aims to guide Hawaii towards confidence in being users and/or creators of technology while empowering youth.

For more information, see [https://technology-outreach-hawaii.github.io/](https://technology-outreach-hawaii.github.io/).

contents.name: Learn Linux
contents.description:
If you want to learn Linux, but don't have any prior knowledge, then the Udemy Course "Learn Linux in 5 Days" might be just what you need!

* You need no prior knowledge to benefit from this course.
* You will be guided step by step using a logical and systematic approach.
* As new concepts, commands, or jargon are encountered they are explained in plain language, making it easy for anyone to understand.
* As an added bonus for enrolling in the Learn Linux in 5 Days video training course, you'll receive a step-by-step checklist and video that teaches you how to install WordPress on an Ubuntu Linux system.
* You'll learn how to install a web server, how to install a database server, how to create database users, and how to configure WordPress. 

Learn more at [https://www.udemy.com/learn-linux-in-5-days/](https://www.udemy.com/learn-linux-in-5-days/)

contents.name: Learn Unity
contents.description:
This Udemy course teaches you how to create simple games in C# using Unity 3D, the free-to-use game development tool. 

We start super simple so you need no prior experience or Unity of coding! With our online tutorials, you'll be amazed what you can achieve. What will you get from this course?

* Learn C#, a powerful modern language.
* Develop a positive attitude to problem solving.
* Gain an excellent general knowledge of game creation.
* Learn how object oriented programming works in practice.
* Transfer your knowledge to .NET, other languages, and more. 

Learn more at [https://www.udemy.com/unitycourse/](https://www.udemy.com/unitycourse/)

contents.name: Career Fair
contents.description:
Whether you are a freshman or a senior, attending the UH Career Fair is a hugely valuable way to learn about future employment (both locally and on the mainland) and meet face-to-face with recruiters in a relaxed setting.

The purpose of this career fair is to provide students with the tools and resources to make important and valuable career decisions. During the Career Fair, you will take your “first steps” toward meaningful employment by meeting with employers face to face to exchange information. 

Learn more at: [http://manoa.hawaii.edu/careercenter/students/career-fair/](http://manoa.hawaii.edu/careercenter/students/career-fair/)

contents.name: WRENCH Project
contents.description:
Hone your C++, distributed systems, and software engineering chops by participating in the WRENCH research project, led by Professor Henri Casanova. WRENCH is  an open-source C++ framework to aid in the development of simulators of distributed computing systems. Version 1.6 of the software is planned to be released in early  May 2020. WRENCH developers employ standard software engineering practices and tools (github, continuous integration with Travis and Docker, testing with Google Test, code coverage with Codecov, code quality measures with  Codacy, and many more).  

This project, although  not very  large yet (10,000 lines of C++ code) is relatively complex. Because of the typical drive-to-publish-result constraint, although the code is reasonably well-implemented  (and very well documents), it could be vastly improved in terms of code re-use, modularity, C++-ness, templating, development of examples, high-level documentation, code coverage, etc.  Because this is a research project (funded by the NSF), the project participants are constantly pushing the research agenda and cannot invest too much time in the software itself (they still do  too much of it, which is why the code is as good as it is, but not enough). 

More details are available at: [https://wrench-project.org/](https://wrench-project.org/).


This is a pure development situation in which the student would come in as a "C++ ninja" and would make series of suggestions, improvements, and contributions to the source code. An applicant that already has great C++ chops would be ideal, but a motivated applicant that would see this as an opportunity to gain great C++ chops will of course be considered. It is also expected that the student would learn about WRENCH and what it is used for, contribute to ongoing WRENCH development efforts, and also contribute to various projects that are currently developing extensions to WRENCH and/or simulators that use WRENCH.

Apply by e-mailing Prof. Casanova at henric@hawaii.edu mentioning "Wrench Project"

contents.name: Club
contents.description: A student club or professional organization related to computer science.

contents.name: Event
contents.description: An event related to computer science.

contents.name: Internship
contents.description: An internship related to computer science.

contents.name: Online Learning
contents.description: A course or other extracurricular online learning opportunity.

contents.name: Project
contents.description: A project related to computer science.

contents.comments: Lecture can be boring. Tests can be tricky... so pay attention and read the questions and answers twice before answering them. Lab is were all the fun is. If you're not an ICS major or don't like programing, you probably shouldn't take the course.

ACM Manoa is a great all in one club that gives students a place to meet other computer science majors and enthusiasts. Joining ACM’s Discord is the best way to stay informed. Underneath ACM are Special Interest Groups such as Grey Hats, Game Dev, and Algorithms. If any of these interest you, this is definitely the place to go.

I understand how Discrete Math relates to Information and Computer Science, but I still didn't enjoy this course-- the content, that is. Initially the homework problems were, to me, difficult. Fortunately, the professor tried very hard to teach the concepts well, and I received a lot of help from the TA and the professor during office hours.

I've heard a lot about how this course is the bottleneck for progressing through the ICS program. Compared to all the courses I've taken before, this has to be the most time consuming. It's not that the concepts are difficult to understand nor is the courseload that heavy, but I found myself having to put more time to review and understand everything. The class structure for this was inverted, so we watched video lectures in our own time and used class time to do actual problems. I thought it was a better use of class time.

The course was very fun in learning how to do the projects we did in ICS 111. The projects weren't hard for beginner programmers and were interesting to get them to have more fun with programming. The only downside was that the class didn't fully prepare you for ICS 211 where the fun little projects became assignments focused on the next stage of programming. There isn't much new students can do in terms of preparing for ICS 211 from ICS 111 since it is based on what you learn, but the things that you do learn may prove useful.

The main thing one can learn from this course is Server Query Language or SQL. This is a great language to learn since it is the most common programming language used to manipulate or manage a database.  Knowing SQL can be a useful skill since it is sought after by employers in positions and fields that are not strictly ICS related.  For example, any business that uses a database to function requires it, including retailers, hospitals, banks, et cetera. With that said, I highly recommend taking this course to learn this invaluable language. One nice thing about taking this course is that the professor records his in-class lectures.  Bear in mind that the purpose of this is not to encourage students to get lazy and not attend his class.  I would not recommend this since there are times when his recordings do not cover solutions that he explains exclusively to those who attend his class.  Instead, the advantage of having these recordings available will allow one to rewatch the lecture in case he or she gets stuck and has a \"How do I do this again?\" moment.
Helping high school students learn about computer science is very rewarding. Paying it forward to help Hawaii kids find their passion.

The ICS 331 Machine programming course teaches students how to read and use binary and hex-based coding. The assignments are very interesting because you get to mess around with a program that allows you to make and manipulate a virtual circuit. The downside is unless you plan on working with low level language code, the material you learn in this class may be irrelevant to what you will do in the future. That being said, I did enjoy the class and the assignments, and I advise that you should take the time to learn about binary and hex coding anyway.

I participated in several HACC events. As others have mentioned, this hackathon differs in the way that it offers participants an entire month to flesh out their ideas and develop their apps, so judges really do expect a lot more and have higher standards when evaluating our final submissions. I would recommend everyone to participate in this challenge to get the feel of competing in a hackathon without the pressure to finish in only a few days. It’s also a great opportunity to go outside of your comfort zone to find the best solution for your challenge, even if it’s not a language or framework that you’re intimately familiar with. My favorite part of this event is seeing all the amazing apps that teams have developed at the end of the month. It’s extremely inspiring and motivating to see everyone’s finished product and encourages me to start my own side projects.

ACM Manoa is an excellent club to join. You can meet other ICS students, ask questions, get help on courses. The several interest groups are great. It is a real help for your undergraduate experience.
